bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, July 24, 1947

div1.p: Kean discusses his case of yellow fever. He maintains that there is no proof Ames ever contracted yellow fever. He writes that Lazear conducted secret experiments, and discusses Moran's draft of his memoirs.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, July 24, 1947

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
24 July '47

div1.p:
Yesterday I came across your very
interesting letter of Feb, 19 with its equal-
ly interesting inclosures, and read them
over carefully- This much cluttered up
old desk of mine is not an office of
record and I have no copies of
letters sent, so, tho. I remember read-
ing you letter, I am not sure that I
answered it- I have a small book
in which I try to keep a record of letters
received and sent, and I do not find
any record of a letter to you, between Feb
23 when it came and March 17 which
may have been a delayed answer.
Your letter contained photostat copies
of the temperature chart and clinical
2
record by Lambert of my case of yellow
fever- They let me go to my quarters
on the 10th day which is in accordance
with my recollection, for I remember
that I was very anxious to get to my
quarters where I could write to my
wife and make an application for
sick leave- I was feeling quite weak
and “rocky” but was in a hurry to get
to see her, as she was in the ninth month
of pregnancy- In fact the baby, my son
Robert, came on July 5- before I got to
New York- She was with her parents in
New Jersey- I was glad to note that
there was nothing on the clinical history
to indicate any excitement or carrying
on such as Lambert has charged to me
subsequently- I think that that, like Dr-
Ames “experimental attack” of yellow fever
3
was a subsequent secretion of what
the french call an idée fixe - an obsession.
The letters of Dr. Berry are certainly
curious- He seems to be perfectly sincere
and honest but to have made no effort
to find out the facts- There is no evi-
dence that he ever read Reed's reports
of the establishment of Camp Lazear
and of the experimental cases- In Reeds
Additional Note which is really the main
Report of his Commission, he mentions
carefully the immunes at the Camp and
that Dr. Roger P. Ames, in charge, was
an immune- In fact I never heard
of Ames' attack of yellow fever until
years after, when Gen. Ireland, the
Surgeon General at the time, called me
up on the prove and asked me if I have
ever heard of a case of yellow fever
that lasted only 5 days, I said no I had'nt-
Well, he said, in “a report of the Hospital
4
at Columbia Bks. Ames is reported as having
been sick with yellow fever but he was
in hospital only 5 days-” I laughed
and said, Ames always claimed to be an
immune and I never heard of his
having yellow fever, but as he is an expert
in that disease I guess they accepted
his diagnosis- Neither Gen. Ireland nor
I believe that he ever had yellow fever-
I do not know the date of this attack of
mild fever, It may have been while I was
absent on sick leave- But it is certainly
a great stretch of the imagination for Dr Berry
to say in his letter to the Journal of the
American Med Assn of Feb, 1 1907 “Only
three physicians Drs Lazear, Carroll
and Ames allowed themselves to be
bitten by infected mosquitoes etc.”
As you say Ames never stated positively
that he was an experimental case for the
records are against him, but the reply
5-
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
that Dr, Berry quotes Ames to have
made in a letter to him is certainly
a model of what the lawyers call
the suggestio falsi - Mrs. Ames in her
long talk with me when she was trying
to have his name added to the Yellow
Fever Roll of Honor, never made any
such claim- It would have been a
powerful argument, if she believed it-
This that I have written is in response
to your request for comment- If it
has been made before, you will excuse
it- What Ames meant by the “unreported
experimental cases” I do not know- There
were unreported experiments, made by
putting infected mosquitoes on some of the
young doctors at the Columbia Barracks Hospital
by Lazear, but as this was done while Reed was away
6
in the United States in August 1900 I
think, and before the Carroll and Lazear
cases occurred, and the knowledge that
there was an interval of two weeks before
the infected mosquitoes became infectious.
They caused no illness, and were never counted.
Lazear conducted these experiments in
secret, for fear the Comd'g Officer might hear
of this violation of the quarantine order-
Dr. Pinto was one of these cases- None of these
doctors after Lazear's death, came forward
and offered to be bitten by a ripe mosquito.
The last one of these secret experiments,
and the only one which was reported by
Reed successful, was that of Dean which
was case no. 11 in Table III, the X Y of Reed's
Preliminary Note (p. 62)- Carroll was no, 10 in
that reportTable III and the others were the youngsters
about the hospital, who regarded it as a
joke since none of them believed in the
Finlay theory- So none of the first nine who
did not volunteer with the knowledge that they
7
were risking their lives, and who did not
suffer an attack of y. f. were considered for
the Roll of Honor- There was also no way
of prooving their names, as Lazear and Reed
were dead and Lazear's notebook from
which Reed got his knowledge of them had
disappeared - before the Roll of Honor Act was passed of course Ames could not
have been one of these cases as he was
known to be immune and was was selected
by Reed to have charge of Camp Lazear
largely because of that fact-

I have just yesterday received a letter
from John Moran- He has sent me a copy
of the first two or three sheets of his memoirs
and has asked me to cross out anything
with which I am not in accord-
It does not tell anything about himself
but is, almost from the beginning, a very
aggressive attack on the Cubans and
especially the Cuban Medical Profession
for their failure to give proper credit for
the demonstration of the Finlay theory to Reed
Ac
K
but to claim it all for Finlay- It is
too partisan in tone to do any good
and will just aggrevate the dispute- I
think that the Americans are not without
blame in this as Finlay is given little credit
by doctors and newspaper men in the U. S.
I will answer Moran's letter tomorrow and
urge him to tell a little about himself and
his early life and approach the Episode
naturally and gradually and then to
discuss it calmly and without adjectives
and partisanship- He might end by discuss-
ing why it was if the whole merit was
Finlay's that Finlay had by voice and pen
stated his discovery to the doctors of Havana
for 10 years and made not a convert except
his disciple Delgado- Yet when Reed made
his demonstation at Camp Lazear in a few months
he converted them all and then the medical
World- So we should consider this scientific
question with scientific detachment and
not with the partisan spirit of a political matter-

I think I have discussed the matter, without starting another
sheet.

closer.seg:
P. S. I have written my reply
on note paper and has sealed
it in a small envelope when
on glancing again at your letter
I saw that Dr. Berrys letters
were to be returned “at my
convenience” I am afraid I have
made a large use of that phrase!
But better late than never-
Your friend sincerely
J. R. Kean
I am using your fine large envelope-
which is better than any which I have-
